They are considered to be "secondary" endosymbionts, meaning they are not essential for the survival of the aphid host, but can provide various beneficial effects, such as increased resistance to parasites, pathogens, or environmental stresses.

The genome of Candidatus Regiella endosymbionts is typically reduced in size compared to free-living bacteria, as they have evolved to rely on their host for many essential metabolic functions. They are vertically transmitted, passed on from one generation of aphids to the next through the female reproductive system.

This specific endosymbiont, Candidatus Regiella endosymbiont of Tuberolachnus salignus, has been found to play a role in the host's adaptation to its environment and may provide enhanced protection against natural enemies or environmental stressors that affect the willow aphid, Tuberolachnus salignus.
